text: I'd strongly advise including Active Tuberculosis Disease as an option for underlying conditions. There's limited evidence so far that it's a risk factor for COVID severity, but I think that's likely because most research has focused on countries with low TB incidence. Given that chronic respiratory disease is already a major risk factor and TB is predominantly a pulmonary disease, it's highly likely that it will emerge as a risk factor for COVID, especially in countries like Ethiopia with a high TB burden. <@U0107EMK8UD> <@U0107DX4VNU> <@U010YC7MX2Q>

elements.text: I'd strongly advise including Active Tuberculosis Disease as an option for underlying conditions. There's limited evidence so far that it's a risk factor for COVID severity, but I think that's likely because most research has focused on countries with low TB incidence. Given that chronic respiratory disease is already a major risk factor and TB is predominantly a pulmonary disease, it's highly likely that it will emerge as a risk factor for COVID, especially in countries like Ethiopia with a high TB burden.

text: Good point, <@U010T8D05UM>. The thought is that respiratory disease/lung disease option incorporates TB, as TB is literally translated as “lung disease” in Amharic

text:
<@U01078QCG2C> thank you for all you do! Based on what we discussed yesterday, here are some things you could make use of.
In order to track PPEs, each hospital needs to first know the rate in which they are using the equipments. So for each equipment, I think we need a weekly rate of usage -see attached excel sheet from the CDC. Maybe, they can make use of this.
As for looking into the quarantine cases, I think it is important to make sure that the facilities that these individuals are being quarantined follow proper guidelines or at the very least are not poor in terms of hygiene due to overcrowding and unavailable resources. Consequently, I was thinking if it would be possible to create a tracking system for medical gears for the different quarantine facilities (similar to what we have for hospitals). We should also try to gather the following data for those in quarantine:
·      Number of confirmed cases from those in the 14-day mandated quarantine
·      Name of facilities along with their capacity
·      Number of people per facility

text: Hi <@U010YC7MX2Q> <@U010U8HF7PY> <@U0107EMK8UD> — as we compile this I think it’s important to note that making too exhaustive a list may mean people won’t complete. Might make sense to weigh that in our decision of what to keep and not. For example, while severe obesity (BMI over 40) has been recently  listed as a risk factor, I’m not sure this underlying condition is prevalent enough in the Ethiopian context to include as we consider limiting the questionnaire. Additionally, i have not seen diarrheal diseases listed as an underlying risk factor anywhere so may vote to not include either. Let me know what you all think.

elements.text: Hi

— as we compile this I think it’s important to note that making too exhaustive a list may mean people won’t complete. Might make sense to weigh that in our decision of what to keep and not. For example, while severe obesity (BMI over 40) has been recently  listed as a risk factor, I’m not sure this underlying condition is prevalent enough in the Ethiopian context to include as we consider limiting the questionnaire. Additionally, i have not seen diarrheal diseases listed as an underlying risk factor anywhere so may vote to not include either. Let me know what you all think.

text: <@U0107DX4VNU> I agree

elements.text: I agree

text: <@U0107DX4VNU> I completely agree!! I have also noted the same thing abt the diarrheal disease in my comments on the doc.

elements.text: I completely agree!! I have also noted the same thing abt the diarrheal disease in my comments on the doc.

text: I agree about making the questionnaire not too exhaustive. The reasoning for BMI also makes sense. With regards to diarrheal diseases, it might have not been noted in the literature because the prevalence of diarrheal diseases is way too low in countries where COVID-19 is highly prevalent at the moment. According to the most recent literature, diarrheal diseases are ranked #3 in causing death in Ethiopia.

text: I think <@U01051X26HJ> is the only admin for the repo. Yes, you should fork the project and submit your PR from there. Everyone is required to submit a PR unless it’s the Admin—ideally the Admin should also but in case of a quick-fix they don’t—so just make sure to tag someone else to check your code before merging.
